questions.text: A mother brings her child Ramini to the clinic, reporting weakness in the lower limbs, with the child being unable to stand up from a sitting position. Upon examination, a positive Gower’s sign is noted, and further evaluation reveals elevated creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels. Considering the clinical findings and history provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Duchenne muscular dystrophy

 

Option D:

 

  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy is due to the mutation in Dystrophin gene, leading to deficiency of Dystrophin protein (subsarcolemmal protein) which leads to muscle necrosis.
  • It is an X linked recessive inherited disease.
  • Calf hypertrophy may be “pseudohypertrophy” due to increased collagen deposit.
  • Positive Gower sign indicates lower limb proximal muscle weakness.
  • Raised CPK levels in a male with weakness in lower limbs is indicative of Duchenne muscular hypertrophy.
  • The serum CK level is consistently greatly elevated in DMD, even in pre-symptomatic stages, including at birth. The usual serum concentration is 15,000-35,000 IU/L (normal <160 IU/L)
  • Mild mental retardation and Waddling gait are also present.
  • Onset: 3-5 years, Wheelchair bound by 12 yrs, death at 25 years due to Resp failure.
  • Muscle biopsy- deficient Dystrophin protein
  • No effective therapy. Steroids can decrease necrosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Myotonic dystrophy: This is a different form of muscular dystrophy that typically includes myotonia (difficulty relaxing muscles) and would not usually present with a positive Gower's sign as an early symptom.

 

Option B: Spinal Muscular atrophy: While this condition also leads to muscle weakness, it does not typically present with elevated CPK levels and Gower’s sign.

 

Option C: Myotonia dystrophica congenita: This term is not commonly used; congenital myotonic dystrophy might present early in life but with different clinical features and not typically with a positive Gower’s sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The child's difficulty standing up from a sitting position, demonstrated by a positive Gower’s sign, along with elevated CPK levels, is characteristic of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD)

 

Ref- Nelson 20th Edition, Page No- 2976 to 2977.

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn is brought to a hospital with symptoms of vomiting and an inability to pass meconium since birth. The physical examination reveals a noticeably distended abdomen and visible peristaltic waves. An X-ray of the abdomen shows a dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with air-fluid levels, but no air is seen beyond the proximal duodenum, suggesting a lack of passage through the distal duodenum and small intestine. Based on the clinical presentation and X-ray findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenal atresia

 

Option B:

 

Double bubble" sign- This is the hallmark finding on X-ray. It shows a dilated stomach and a dilated duodenal bulb, creating the appearance of two bubbles side by side. The narrowed segment of the duodenum between these two bubbles causes the obstruction.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Projectile vomiting: Infants with duodenal atresia often have projectile vomiting, which can occur shortly after feeding. The vomiting is typically non-bilious, meaning it does not contain bile.
  • Abdominal distension: Due to the blockage in the duodenum, there is a build-up of fluid and gas in the stomach and proximal small intestine. This can cause abdominal distension and visible peristaltic waves.
  • Failure to pass meconium: Meconium is the first stool that newborn passes, and its absence can indicate a bowel obstruction.
  • Absent or decreased bowel sounds: A blockage in the duodenum can cause decreased or absent bowel sounds upon auscultation.
  • Polyhydramnios: In some cases, polyhydramnios (excessive amniotic fluid) may be present during pregnancy, which can be a sign of duodenal atresia in the fetus.
  • Down syndrome: Duodenal atresia is commonly associated with Down syndrome, and infants with this genetic condition may be screened for the condition.
  • Other associated anomalies: In some cases, duodenal atresia may be associated with other congenital anomalies such as cardiac defects, tracheoesophageal fistula, or imperforate anus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Esophageal atresia: Esophageal atresia is a congenital condition characterized by a gap or blockage in the esophagus. It typically presents shortly after birth with drooling, choking, and difficulty swallowing, but it does not typically present with failure to pass meconium or a distended abdomen with visible peristaltic waves. Additionally, the X-ray findings described are not consistent with esophageal atresia.

 

Option C. Hirschsprung's disease: Hirschsprung's disease is a congenital condition characterized by the absence of nerve cells in parts of the large intestine, leading to difficulty passing stool. It typically presents with symptoms of intestinal obstruction, such as failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, and vomiting. However, the X-ray findings described, including a dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with air-fluid levels, are more indicative of a small bowel obstruction rather than Hirschsprung's disease, which primarily affects the large intestine.

 

Option D. Jejunal atresia: Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition characterized by a blockage or narrowing in the jejunum, a part of the small intestine. It can present with symptoms similar to duodenal atresia, including vomiting, failure to pass meconium, and abdominal distension. However, the X-ray findings described, specifically the visualization of a dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with air-fluid levels, are more suggestive of a proximal small bowel obstruction, which is consistent with duodenal atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duodenal atresia is a congenital condition characterized by a blockage or narrowing in the duodenum, the first part of the small intestine. It commonly presents in newborns with vomiting, failure to pass meconium, and a distended abdomen with visible peristaltic waves. X-ray findings typically show a dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with air-fluid levels.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter- 356, – Page No- 7749.

choices.text: It’s a true diverticulum.
It is due to persistence of omphalomesenteric duct.
May have ectopic acid-secreting gastric mucosa.
Least common congenital anomaly of gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 3-year-old son, who has no significant medical history, to the pediatric clinic after discovering bright red blood in his diaper. The child seems relatively comfortable, except for when his right lower quadrant (RLQ) is palpated, causing him to cry. An ultrasound reveals a tubular blind-ending structure originating from an ileal loop, and a technetium-99m scan confirms the presence of Meckel's diverticulum. Considering the diagnosis of Meckel's diverticulum, which of the following statements is NOT true about its features?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Least common congenital anomaly of gastrointestinal tract

 

Option D:

 

Meckel’s diverticulum:

 

Congenital diverticulum presenting in childhood

 

It’s a “true” diverticulum, with all 3 layers of the gut wall out pouched

 

Pathogenesis

 

  • Persistence of vitelline (omphalomesenteric) duct in small intestine  
  • May have ectopic acid-secreting gastric or pancreatic tissue

 

Presentation:

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Painless rectal bleeding -due to gastric acid secretion causing damage to small bowel tissue
  • Normal abdominal examination
  • May serve as lead point for intussusception
  • Small bowel obstruction

 

Evaluation

 

Most commonly discovered as incidental finding on laparotomy

 

  • Technetium-99m scan aka Meckel scan
  • Most accurate test
  • Technetium-99m pertechnetate radioisotope is taken up by ectopic gastric mucosa

 

Treatment: Surgical removal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. True Diverticulum: Correct. Meckel's diverticulum involves all layers of the bowel wall.

 

Option B. Persistence of Omphalomesenteric Duct: Correct, as Meckel's diverticulum results from the failure of the omphalomesenteric duct to completely obliterate during development.

 

Option C. Ectopic Acid-Secreting Gastric Mucosa: Correct. The presence of ectopic gastric mucosa can lead to acid secretion and subsequent ulceration, causing bleeding, which might explain the rectal bleeding in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Most common congenital anomaly of gastrointestinal tract - Meckel’s diverticulum

 

Rule of 2’s

 

  • Affects 2% of population
  • 2 feet from ileocecal valve
  • 2 inches long
  • 2 types of epithelia tissue: gastric and pancreatic
  • Male: female ratio 2:1
  • Patients < 2 years old
  • 2% symptomatic

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition Chapter 357 – Page No- 7762

choices.text: The diagnosis based on the clinical feature is Klippel Feil Syndrome
Pathology is due to defective somite development between 3rd and 8th week of foetal development
Torticollis is a key finding in this syndrome
Triad of this disease includes low posterior hair line, short neck and limitations of neck movement

questions.text: A child is brought to the clinic by their mother due to restricted neck movements. Upon examination, an X-ray reveals non-segmentation of the cervical vertebrae. Considering the clinical presentation and radiographic findings, all of the following statements are accurate about the condition except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Torticollis is a key finding in this Syndrome

 

Option C:

 

In Klippel Feil syndrome, there is congenital short and stiff neck due to fused or deformed cervical vertebrae. It occurs due to failure of normal segmentation of cervical vertebra somite between 3rd and 8th week of foetal development. Characterized by Feil’s Triad: low posterior hair line, short neck, limitations of head and neck movement.

 

While torticollis (abnormal, asymmetrical head or neck position) can be associated with Klippel-Feil Syndrome due to the abnormal cervical spine structure, it is not considered a key or defining feature of the syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Klippel-Feil Syndrome diagnosis: This is true based on the described clinical presentation and radiographic findings.

 

Option B: Defective somite development: This is accurate as the syndrome results from errors in the segmentation of somites during early fetal development.

 

Option D: Disease triad: The described triad is characteristic of Klippel-Feil Syndrome and is accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klippel-Feil Syndrome is characterized by the congenital fusion of any two of the seven cervical vertebrae. It is indeed due to abnormal segmentation during early fetal development. The classical clinical triad includes a low posterior hairline, a short neck, and limited neck movement.

 

Ref- Nelson 20th Edition page 3803

choices.text: It is due to the hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles
1st born female child has more risk of developing it
Paradoxical Aciduria is a feature of this disease.
Baby manifests on the day of delivery itself.

questions.text: A mother brings her 24-day-old male infant to the clinic with a 4-day history of vomiting. The infant appears dehydrated and irritable upon physical examination. Laboratory tests reveal hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. With these findings, a diagnosis of Infantile Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (IHPS) is made. Which of the following statements about IHPS is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paradoxical Aciduria is a feature of this disease.

 

Option C:

 

Paradoxical aciduria is a characteristic feature of IHPS. Despite systemic alkalosis due to repeated vomiting, the kidneys excrete alkaline urine due to the body's attempt to conserve chloride, leading to paradoxical aciduria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: It is due to the hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles: This statement is false. IHPS is primarily characterized by the hypertrophy of the circular muscles of the pylorus, not the longitudinal muscles.

 

Option B: The first-born female child has a higher risk of developing it: This statement is false. IHPS is more common in first-born male infants, not females.

 

Option D: The baby manifests symptoms on the day of delivery itself: This statement is false. Symptoms of IHPS typically start between the 2nd and 8th weeks of life, not on the day of delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IHPS involves hypertrophy of the circular pyloric muscle, is more common in first-born males, typically presents between 2 to 6 weeks after birth, and can lead to paradoxical aciduria is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.
 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition Chapter- 355â€“ Page No- 7733.

questions.text: A 27-day-old male infant is brought to the clinic by his mother due to episodes of projectile vomiting. Physical examination reveals a palpable mass on palpation/auscultation (P/A) with observable peristaltic waves moving from left to the right side. Ultrasonography shows a "target sign," and blood tests indicate hypokalemia with acidic urine. Considering the clinical presentation and ultrasound findings, which medication taken prenatally is most associated with the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Erythromycin

 

Option D:

 

The clinical findings are suggestive of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS), a condition characterized by the narrowing of the pylorus leading to projectile vomiting. The "target sign" on ultrasonography is a classic sign of HPS. Erythromycin use, particularly in the early postnatal period, has been associated with an increased incidence of HPS. Although the prenatal role of erythromycin is less clear, it is the most likely medication among the options provided to be associated with this condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Penicillin: There is no established link between prenatal penicillin exposure and the development of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

 

Option B. Dexamethasone: This medication is not typically associated with HPS. It is a corticosteroid often used prenatally to accelerate lung maturity but does not have a known causal relationship with HPS.

 

Option C. Lithium: Lithium use during pregnancy is associated with congenital cardiac anomalies, particularly Ebstein anomaly, rather than HPS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An infant presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting, palpable abdominal mass, hypokalemia, and aciduria, alongside ultrasound evidence of the "target sign," is indicative of Infantile Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (IHPS). Maternal erythromycin intake is a risk factor for IHPS. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, supported by ultrasonography findings of increased pyloric muscle thickness. While IHPS is a medical emergency, the definitive treatment is surgical via Ramstedt pyloromyotomy.

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition Chapter- 355– Page No- 7733.

questions.text: During a routine pediatric consultation, you observe a 4-year-old child accompanied by his family, all of whom share a similar height. Upon examination, you notice limb shortening and disproportionate short stature in the child. Considering the family history and clinical presentation, you suspect a genetic condition characterized by an inherited defect in enchondral ossification due to an FGFR3 mutation. After a thorough evaluation, you explain to the parents that this condition is inherited and, unfortunately, there are limited treatment options available. Based on the history and clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Achondroplasia

 

Option C:

 

  • Achondroplasia is an AD disorder because of mutation in FGFR3 gene.
  • It leads to abnormal enchondral ossification.
  • Rizhomelic limb shortening
  • Disproportionate short stature
  • Champagne glass pelvis appearance on X ray.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Osteogenesis imperfecta: This condition involves a genetic defect leading to brittle bones that fracture easily, not primarily associated with short stature or FGFR3 mutations.

 

Option B: Growth hormone deficiency: This condition leads to short stature due to insufficient growth hormone production, but it does not typically result in disproportionate limb shortening and is not caused by FGFR3 mutations.

 

Option D: Constitutional delay: This refers to a temporary delay in growth and development, with children eventually catching up to their peers. It does not involve disproportionate limb shortening or FGFR3 mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achondroplasia, an autosomal dominant condition, characterized by disproportionate short stature, limb shortening, and a normal-sized torso. It is caused by a mutation in the FGFR3 gene, which leads to abnormal cartilage formation and enchondral ossification

 

Ref-Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter – 721 Page No 14415.

questions.text: A full-term newborn is brought to the clinic by her mother, who reports that the baby starts coughing during feeding attempts, leading to significant feeding difficulties over the last 2 days. The examination reveals signs of dehydration in the baby. An X-ray is performed, showing an anomaly suggestive of a congenital condition affecting the esophagus. Based on the clinical presentation and X-ray findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Esophageal atresia with TEF

 

The given X-ray is showing the nasogastric tube inserted into the baby's nose and into the stomach has coiled within the upper pouch of the esophagus instead of advancing down to the stomach due to the presence of the fistula.

 

The baby is presenting with drooling of saliva because of the atresia and coughing during breast feeding because of the TEF.

 

The M/c type of TEF is type C

 

Clinical manifestations-

 

  • Excessive salivation.
  • Coughing, choking, cyanosis,
  • Apnea
  • Abdominal distention.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Esophageal atresia: While esophageal atresia alone can cause feeding difficulties, the coughing during feeding is more indicative of the additional presence of TEF.

 

Option C. Physiological phenomenon: Coughing during feeding and signs of dehydration in a newborn are not physiological and suggest a pathological process.

 

Option D: Galactosemia: This is a metabolic disorder that present with acidic stool, not with coughing during feeding as an initial symptom and is not detectable on an X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The symptoms of coughing during feeds and signs of dehydration in a newborn, along with an abnormal X-ray of the esophagus, are highly suggestive of esophageal atresia with or without tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition – Page No- 7661-7667.
